p.seg: Even if there is no event [to be recorded in the first month]
the Text invariably mentions the first month
This is because it pays careful attention to beginnings of things.
When it comes to the duke, why does the Text not state: [the duke] ascended the throne?
In order to give full expression to the duke's determination.
In what way does the Text give full expression to his determination?
In pointing out the ruler's not choosing to become duke.
The ruler's not choosing to become duke,
what does that mean?
It means that [Yiin] by this means he intended to resign in favour of Hwan.
Was it correct to resign in favour of Huán?
The answer is
that it was not correct
The Chūnqiū is [generally] complete on people's good points
and is not complete on people's bad points.
Although Yiin was not being correct, the Text is explicit on this point.
Why is that?
The Text intends thereby to make explicit a bad point concerning Hwan.
That the Text should make explicit a bad point
why is that?
Since Yiin intended to resign [in favour of Hwan] and Hwan assassinated him,
it was obvious that Hwan was evil.
Since Hwan was the one who assassinated Yiin and Yiin was the one who [intended to] resign [in favour of Hwan],
it is obvious that Yiin was good.
Since he was good, how can he than [be said to] have been incorrect in this respect?
The Chuenchiou values righteousness, but does not value [mere expressions of] favour.
It seeks to extend the correct principles and does not seek to extend the corrupt ones (a).
A filial son displays the good qualities of his father,
but does not display his evil qualities.
That the late lord wished to hand over [the title] to Hwan
was by no means correct,
it was pernicious.
He may have been like that,
but in the end he overcame his pernicious intentions and gave the title to Yiin.
If Yiin had ascertained the pernicious determination of the former ruler
who intended eventually to hand over the title to Hwan,
this was in fact to give full expression to his father's evil.
The institution of elder brothers and younger brothers
belong to the human relationships determined by Heaven:
the one who is a son receives his status from his father;
the one who is a feudal prince receives his status from his lord.
Having abrogated the human relationships determined by Heaven
and having forgotten his ruler and father
in order to perform an act of small kindness,
[Yiin] (p.70) may be said to have followed a small path.
A man like Yiin
may be said to have made light of a state of a thousand chariots,
while he was not yet able to
tread the right way.
1.2 In the third month
the duke and Yi-fuu of Juliuh made a covenant on Mieh.
What is meant by the term jí?
[It indicates that] the Interior (i.e. the state of Luu) took the initiative with regard to this meeting.
Yi
is [his] style.
Fù
has approximately the same meaning as fù ('teacher').
It is an honorific designation used by men.
Why
is he not referred to as the viscount of Ju?
Form oldest times Ju was as insiginificant state
[the rulers of] which had not received investiture from the Jou [king].
[That the Text] does not give the day [of the meeting]
is due to the fact that the convenant was [subsequently] repudiated.
Mieh
is the name of the place [of the meeting].
In summer,
in the fifth month,
the earl of Jenq overcame Duann in Yan.
What is meant by the term kè?
It means néng ('to be able').
To be able to do what?
To be able to kill.
Why does the Text not use the term shā ('to kill')?
In order to make it appear that Duann had many followers.
Duann
was the younger brother of the earl of Jenq.
How do we know [from the wording of the Text] that he was the younger brother?
The state and the title are indicated in the case of rulers who kill their heir or their younger brother (d).
Since this is the case here,
we know that he was the younger brother.
The fact that Duann [Duan
who was a younger brother [of the ruler] and a prince, [was a younger brother
is not explicitly referred to as such [but the text refuses to call him a younger brother; he was a prince, but the text refuses to call him a prince,
indicates that [the Chuenchiou] degrades him. [The text is downgrading him.
Duann had deviated from the correct road to be followed by a son and a younger brother.
[The Chuenchiou] therefore represents Duann as mean and [at the same time] aggravates [the crime of] the earl of Jenq.
What was there to aggravate with regard to [the crime of] the earl of Jenq?
[The Chuenchiou] aggravates the fact that the earl of Jenq had for a long time been determined in his heart
to kill [his brother].
The phrase 'In Yan' indicates
that the place [were [sic!] the killing took place] was far away.
It is the same as to say that the [the earl of Jenq] took a child from its mother's arms and killed it (e).
[The Text] considers that an aggravating circumstance.
Since this is so, what course of action would have been proper for the earl of Jenq?
To be lax in one's pursuit and let escape the culprit,
that is the way in which one treats one's relatives with generosity.
1.4. In Autumn,
in the seventh month,
the King by Heaven's Grace sent the Administrator Sheuan with presents for the funeral of duke Huey and Jonq Tzyy.
A mother has [the name of] her son as family name.
Who was this (p.72) Jonq Tzyy?
[She was] the mother of duke Huey
and the concubine of duke Shiaw.
According to the rites
it was permissible to present funeral gifts to a person's mother,
but it was not permissible to present such gifts to a person`s concubine.
The superior man accepted this (information as an entry in the Chuenchiou) on account of the fact that it was rendered in acceptable terminology.
The making of this entry is due to the fact
that the funeral gifts arrived too late.
What is meant by the term fenq?
A team of four horses is referred to as fenq;
clothing and coverlets are referred to as suey;
cowrie shells and jade are referred to as harn;
money and valuables are referred to as fuh.
In the ninth month
there was a convenant with a man of Sonq in Suh.
Who else participated (in the convenant)?
A man of inferior rank of the Interior.
(The phrase) "a man from Sonq"
denotes a man of inferior rank from the Exterior.
The day is not given for convenants between men of inferior ranks.
Suh
is the name of a city.
In Winter,
in the twelfth month,
the earl of Jay came.
The term lai means
"to come on a court visit".
Why does the Text reject the use of the term chaur ("to pay a court visit")?
(The envoy) was a feudal lord enfeoffed (with land) within the Royal Domain
and could therefore not leave (his post) and take part in meetings with other feudal lords
without being ordered to do so by the Son of Heaven.
(The Chuenchiou) considers him at fault for having relations abroad
and is therefore not willing to grant the use of the term chaur.
Bows used on missions of friendly enquiries and the how arrows (a)
do not travel outside the borders (of the state);
bundled and dried meat
is not carried within the borders (b).
When there is one in the most exalted position
(his subjects) do not match him (c).
Gongtzyy Yih-shy died.
To give the day of the death of a great officer
is the norm.
Omission of the day of the death
indicates condemnation.
In the second year,
in Spring,
the duke had a meeting with the Rong in Chyan (a).
The term huey ("to meet")
indicates that the Exterior (party) acted as host of the meeting.
The one who is wise deliberates,
the one who is righteous (p.73) travels (with his lord),
the one who is benevolent guards (the state in the absence of his ruler) (b).
Only when he has (secured himself of the services of) these three (assistants)
may (the ruler) go abroad to participate in meetings.
(The phrase) "had a meeting with the Rong"
implies the the duke was in danger.
In Summer,
in the fifth month,
men from Jeu entered Shianq.
The term ruh ("to enter") implies that
those who are inside (the attacked city) refuse to receive (those who enter).
Shianq
was one of our cities.
Wu-shiee led an army and entered Jyi.
The term ruh ("to enter") implies
that those who are inside (the attacked city) refuse to receive (those who enter).
Jyi
was a state.
The one who recklessly sets his mind on entering the territory of others
will in turn have his own territory entered.
The ommission of the family name (of Wu-gai) implies
degradation owing to the fact that he brought extinction to (whose ruler had) the same clan name
(as the ruler of the state of Lu).
In Autumn in the eights month, on the day geng-chern,
the ruler had a meeting with the Rong in Tarng. [[made a covenant of allegiance, I'm afraid]]
In the ninth month,
Lii-shiu of Jih came to meet the bride (of his ruler).
The meeting of a bride
is the personal affair (of the bridegroom).
To employ a great officer as an envoy,
is not the correct norm.
That (the name of) the state is here used as the family name
is due to the fact that he (Lii-shiu) came and had official contacts with us.
For that reason the superior man promotes him.
In Winter,
in the tenth month,
the (duke's) eldest daughter went to married (in the state of) Jih.
In the rituals,
to be married, of women, is referred to as guei ("to return").
to be divorced is referred to as lai guei ("to return home").
(These expressions signify that) a woman is (always) subordinated to a man:
while still at home
she is governed by her father;
when she has married
she is governed by her husband;
after the death of her husband
she follows her eldest son.
A woman does not travel alone, (act on her own initiative?)
but is necessarily accompanied. (necessarily follows someone else's commands)
Why does the Text here employs a phrase - "the (duke's) eldest daughter went to be married in (the state of) Jih" -
that makes it seem as if she travelled alone?
The answer is:
it was not a case of her travelling alone.
It was our eldest daughter who went to married in Jih;
therefore the Text records it.
Why does the Text not use the term "envoy"? ("ordered her to...)
The circumstances of meeting a bride
were not (sufficiently) significant to be treated (in great detail).
Tzyy-bor of Jih (?) and the viscount of Jeu jad a meeting in Mih (a).
Some say: the viscount of Jih treated the viscount of Jeu as the elder and made a covenant with him.
Other say: their ages and rank being the same.
The viscount of Jih took precedence by (claiming) seniority.
In the twelfth month,
on the day yii-mao,
the duke's wife, lady Tzyy, died.
When a lady dies
the place (of her death) is not recorded.
The term furen ("lady")
refers to the wife of Yiin.
The Text records the death but not the burial.
The significance of (the terminology applied to ) ladies
is the same as that applied to lords.
Men from Jenq attacked Wei.
In the third year,
in Spring,
in the King's second month,
on the day jii-syh,
the sun was eclipsed.
The Text gives the day and omits the term shuoh ("the first day of the moon")
to indicate that the eclipse occurred
on the last day of the moon.
Why does the Text use the phrase ryh yeou shyr jy ("something is eating the sun")?
In spitting out one ejects what has been removed (a);
in eating one puts it inside.
When what has been removed is missing and cannot be seen,
it is the case of someone having eaten it.
Yeou is an implicit expression;
huoh is an explicit expression (b).
in the phrase you shyr jy
(yeou) is an implicit expression used in connection with the sun.
Why does the Text not indicate who is eating the sun.
To know that this cannot be known,
that is true knowledge.
In the third month,
on the day geng-shiu,
the King by Heaven's Grace died.
The term beng is used of high (mountains),
of massive (objects),
and of the most venerable (persons).
That the term beng is used with reference to the Son of Heaven
is due to his being the most venerable of men.
Why does the Text refer to him as having collapsed?
Because he is high above the people
the Text refers to his death in this way.
Why does the Text not give his personal name?
(The Son of Heaven is) the greatest and most exalted (of men).
Therefore the Text does not give his personal name.
In Summer,
in the fourth month,
on the day shin-mo,
(the head of) the Yiin family died.
Who was this (head of) the Yiin family?
(He was) one of the great officers of the Son of Heaven.
The deaths of great officers of the Exterior are not (normally) recorded.
Why was an entry made here?
On the occasion of the death of the Son of Heaven he acted as host for (the duke of) Luu.
Therefore the Text commiserates him and records his death.
In Autumn,
a son of the Wuu family came and requested money contributions.
Who was this "son of the Wuu family"?
One of the great officers of the Son of Heaven.
Since he was a great officer of the Son of Heaven,
why does the Text refer to him as "the son of the Wuu family"?
The mourning had not yet been completed
and the fatherless son had not yet been invested in his rank.
To employ as an envoy one who has not yet been invested
is not correct.
Why does the Text not refer to him as an envoy?
There was no ruler.
Presentations to the dead are called fenq;
presentations to the living are called fuh.
It is said: to present these gifts
is correct;
to request these gifts
is not correct.
Even if (the house of) Jou had not requested (gifts)
(the house of) Luu would have had to present (them).
Even if (the house of) Luu did not present (gifts)
it was impermissible for (the house of) Jou to request (them).
The term chyou ("to request") is an expression, indicating that the (The basic meaning of qiú)
ultimate outcome, whether positive or negative, (is concerned with getting or not getting. CH???)
cannot be known.
The Text criticizes both parties.
In the eigth month,
on the day geng-chern,
Her, duke of Sonq, died.
It is common praxis (in the Chuenchiou)
to give the day of the death of a feudal lord (a).
In Winter,
in the twelfth month,
On the day goei-wey
there was the burial of duke Miou of Sonq.
The day of the burial is given
in order to indicate that there were unforeseen and irregular occurrences (b).
The performance of the burial was indangered.
In the fourth year,
in Spring,
in the King's second month,
men from Jeu attacked Chii
and took Moulou.
Tradition has it (a)
that the terms fa ("to attack") and cheu ("to take")
condemn condemnation. (?????)
This was the first instance of feudal lords attacking each other
and taking cities from each other.
Therefore the Text carefully records the event.
On the day whu-shen
Jou-shiu of Wei assassinated his lord Wan.
When a great officer assassinates his lord
and (the name of) the state is used in place of his family name
it is a case of arrogation.
He assassinated his lord in order to replace him (a).
In Summer,
the duke and the duke of Sonq met at Ching.
The term jyi ("and") implies
that the Interior took the initiative (to the meeting).
The term yuh ("to meet") implies
that both parties were moved by a common purpose.
The duke of Sonq, the marquis of Chern, men from Tsay and men form Wei attacked Jenq.
In Autumn
Huei led an army, joined the duke of Sonq, the marquis of Chern, men from Tsay and men from Wei and attacked Jenq.
Who was this Huei?
The duke's son Huei.
Why does the Text not refer to him as the duke's son?
In order to degrade him.
Why degrade him?
He (later) participated in the assassination of the duke.
Therefore the Texg degrades him.
In the ninth month
the people of Wei killed Jou-shiu in Pwu.
The use of the term ren ("people") as the agent of killing denotes
the killing of someone guilty.
That Juh-shiu is referred to (simply) by his personal name (a)
indicates the lapse of his attempt at arrogation.
The Text indicates the month
in order to exercize special care.
The phrase "in Pwu"
implies criticism of the fact that the assassin was allowed to escape (abroad) (b).
In Winter,
in the twelfth month,
the people of Wei set up Jinn (as their ruler).
The phrase "the people of Wei"
is an expression denoting a multitude.
The term lih ("to set up") implies that it was not proper to set him up.
The fact that Jinn is referred to by his personal name implies condemnation.
Why does the Text refer to ren ("people") as the agent?
He had gained the support of the masses.
Since this was so, he must in fact have been worthy.
If he was worthy why does the Text state that it was improper to set him up?
According to the doctrine of the Chuenchiou
the status of feudal lord was granted to the proper heir and not to the (one whose moral qualifications made him more) worthy (in the case of feudal lords it sides with... CH)
In the fifth year,
in Spring,
the duke went to see the fish in Tarng (a).
The commentary says:
"The term shyh ("to regard") is used of regular events;
the term guan ("to look at") us used of irregular events."
According to the rites
the (most) venerable (ruler) does not personally attend to petty matters,
and those in mean positions do not supervise great undertakings.
Fishing
is the occupation of those in a mean position.
For the duke to look at this
was not correct.
In Summer,
in the fourth month
there was the burial of duke Hwan of Wei.
The Text gives the month
on account of the irregular circumstances (of this burial).
In Autumn,
an army of Wei entered Shenq.
The term ruh ("to enter")
implies that those who are inside (the attacked city) refuse to receive (those who enter).
Shenq
was a state.
When the commander had mean rank and the troops were numerous the Text refers to the army.
in the ninth month
(the duke) completed the shrine palace of Jonq Tzyy.
What is implied in the term kao?
Kao means
that (the duke) completed it.
(In doing so) he established Jonq Tzyy as the (late) lady.
According to the rites,
when a son of a concubine became ruler
he built a shrine palace for his mother
and made a prince preside at the offerings there.
(These) offerings were presented by the son
and were discontinued by the grandson.
Jonq Tzyy
was the mother of duke Huey.
Yiin was her grandson and yet he repaired (and completed) it.
(The Chuenchiou) considers Yiin at fault. (declares...CH)
For the first time (the duke) presented only six rows of dancers.
Chu
means "for the first time".
Master Guuliang says (a):
"When the great dance was performed
the Son of Heaven employed eight rows of dancers,
the dukes six rows,
and the feudal lords four rows of dancers."
The phrase chu shiann liow yeu indicates
that for the first time the ritual music was usurped (by a feudal lord).
Master Shy says:
When the great dance was performed
the Son of Heaven and the feudal lords alike
employed eight rows of dancers."
The phrase chu shiann liow yeu signifies
that for the first time the music was reduced (?) (b).
Men from Juliuh and men from Jenq attacked Sonq.
This was a calamity occasioned by insects.
In severe cases the month is indicated.
In less severe cases (only) the season is given.
In Winter,
in the twelfth month,
on the day shin-syh,
Gongtzyy Kou died.
Yiin did not invest great officers.
Why, then, does the Text refer to Kou as Gongtzyy?
(He) was a great officer (invested by) the late lord (Shiaw).
Men from Sonq attacked Jenq
and besieged Charngge.
The phrase wei yih ("to besiege a city")
is not used in conjunction with the phrase fa gwo ("to attack a state").
Why does the Text here use the term wei?
(The Chuenchiou) considers that the matter was too protracted.
In attacking one does not exceed one season;
in fighting one does not persue those who flee;
In punishing one does not obstruct those who have given themselves up (a).
To oppress the people (b)（Wang Niansun conjectures: take captives
and to drive away their cattle and horses
is called chin ("to invade");
to destroy trees and demolish houses
is called fa ("to attack").
In the sixth year,
in Spring,
men form Jenq came and made offer of peace (a).
The term shu
means huei ("to destroy").
The (basic etymological???CH) meaning of pyng
"to accomplish peace in accordance with the correct principles".
The phrase lai shu pyng
implies that peace was in fact not achieved.
In Summer,
in the fifth month,
on the day shin-yeou,
the duke had a meeting with the marquis of Chyi
(when they) made a convenant in Ay.
Autumn,
the seventh month.
In Winter,
men from Sonq took Charngge.
The taking of cities of the Exterior was not (normally) recorded.
Why does the Text record this instance?
(The Chuenchiou) considers it (i.e. the siege) too protracted.
In the seventh year,
in Spring,
in the King's third month,
the duke's third daughter went to be married to (the ruler of the state of) Jih.
Why does the Text not use the term nih ("to meet")?
The circumstances of meeting a bride are insignificant
and not worthy of mention.
The marquis of Terng died (a).
The marquises of Terng had no personal names.
When they were young they were called shyh tzyy ("genereation sons");
when they were grown up they were called jiun ("lord").
(Such was the) praxis of the Dyi (barbarians).
(Only) those who were not in direct line of succession were referred to by their personal names.
in Summer
we walled Jongchiou.
Walls
are built for the purpose of protecting the people.
When the population is large and the city is small,
then one makes the city larger.
There should be no limits set with regard to the expansion of cities.
All entries concerning the walling of cities
imply criticism.
The marquis of Chyi sent his younger brother Nian on a mission of friendly enquiries.
The nobility of a feudal lord is such
that younger and elder brothers must not be referred to as belonging to the same category.
That the text here uses the term dih ("younger brother")
is due to the fact that he (Nian) came (to the state of Luu) and had (official) contact with us.
The Text (therefore) refers to his noble status (of the younger brother of a feudal lord).
In Autumn
In Winter,
the King by Heaven's Grace sent the earl of Farn on a mission of friendly enquiries.
The Rong attacked the earl of Farn at Chuunchiou and carried him back (with them).
Who was this earl of Farn?
(He was) a great officer of the Son of Heaven.
The term fa ("to attack") is used only for states.
Why is the term fa here used for a single person?
In order to magnify the appointments of the Son of Heaven.
The term Rong
applies to (the state of) Wei.
Wei is degraded and treated as (on par with) the Rong (barbarians)
on account of the fact that they attacked an envoy of the Son of Heaven.
Chuuchiou
was a city in Wei.
To carry him back (with them)
was even worse than to seize him.
In the eights year,
in Spring,
the duke of Sonq and the marquis of Wei met at Chwei.
To meet without previous appointment is called yuh.
The term yuh implies
that the two parties were moved by a common purpose.
In the third month
the earl of Jenq sent Yeuan to return (the city of) Biing.
The Text gives the personal name of Yeun
as a means of degrading the earl of Jenq
and criticizing his giving away land.
On the day geng-yn
we entered Biing.
The term ruh ("to enter") implies
that those who were inside refused to receive those who entered.
The Text gives the day of entering
in order to condemn those who entered.
This Biing was the place
where the earl of Jenq had received his appointment from the Son of Heaven
and the city used (by the earl of Jenq) during the sacrifices on Mt. Tay.
In Summer,
in the sixth month,
on the day jii-hay,
Kao-fuu, the marquis of Tsay, died.
To give the day of the death of a feudal lord
is the correct norm.
On the day shin-hay
the baron of Suh died.
Suh
was a small state
(the ruler of which) had not yet been able to participate in convenants (with Luu).
Therefore the term nan ("baron") is used in this entry of the death (of the ruler of Suh).
In Autumn,
in the seventh month,
on the day geng-wuu,
the duke of Sonq, the marquis of Chyi and the marquis of Wei made a convenant in Waa-u.
The day is not (normally) given for convenants between states of the Exterior.
Why does the Text give the day here?
This was the first instance of a covenant between three feudal lords.
Therefore the Text exercizes care and records the day.
The praxis of swearing oaths does not go back to (the time) of the Five Emperors;
the institution of covenants does not go back to (the time of) the Three Kings;
the exchange of hostages does not go back to (the time of) the Two Hegemons (a).
In the eights month,
there was the burial of duke Shiun of Tsay.
The Text gives the month to indicate
that there were irregular cicumstances.
In the ninth month,
on the day shin-mao,
the duke and a man from Jeu made a covenant at Baulai.
It is permissible to use the phrase "the duke and a man".
It is impermissible to use the phrase "the duke and a great officer".
There were ming insects (a).
In Winter,
in the twelfth month,
Wu-shiee died.
Nothing has been heard about the reason
why Wu-gai is referred to by his personal name.
Some say (that it was due to the fact) that Yiin did not invest in great officers.
Others say that it is a case of degradation.
In the ninth year,
in Spring,
the King by Heaven's Grace sent Nan Jih to come on a mission of friendly enquiries.
Nan
is the family name (here) used in place of the clan name (a).
Jih
was his style.
Pinn
means "to enquire".
(For the Son of Heaven) to send missions of friendly enquiries to a feudal lord
was not correct.
In the third month,
on the day goei-yeou,
there was great rain,
with thunder and lightning.
Jenn
is thunder;
diann
is lightning.
On the day geng-shern
there was heavy snowfall.
The Text records the frequency (of precipitation) (b).
Within eight days
there were two occurrences of great unnatural events.
The In and the Yang were out of balance.
Therefore the Text exercizes care and records the days of the events.
When the month is given in the case of rain
the entry concerns (rain in) the proper (season).
Shye died.
This Shye
was Suoo Shye.
Since Yiin did not invest great officers
the Text does not refer to Shye as such.
Why did Yiin not invest great officers?
The answer is:
he did not allow himself to be established as the (true) ruler.
In Summer
we walled Lang.
Autumn,
the seventh month.
Since there was no (major) event at this time
why was this entry made?
In order not to neglect (to record) the season.
In Winter
the duke had a meeting with the marquis of Chyi in Biing.
The term huey ("to meet")
implies that the party of the Exterior (state) acted as host of the meeting.
In the tenth year,
in the Spring,
in the King's second month,
the duke had a meeting with marquis of Chyi and the earl of Jenq at Jongchiou.
In Summer,
Huei led an army, joined men from Chyi and men from Jenq and attacked Sonq.
In the sixth month,
on the day ren-shiu,
the duke defeated the army of Sonq at Jian.
The term jann ("to battle") is not used of the Interior. (action initiated by Lu itself??CH)
The Text uses the more important term (i.e. bay "to defeat").
On the day shin-wey (we) took Gaw.
On the day shin-syh (we) took Farng.
The Text does not (normally) give the day in case of the capture of cities.
Why does the Text give the day in this instance?
(The Chuenchiou) considers it improper that he (i.e. Yiin) took advantage of the defeated enemy and sought to extend his profit
by the capture of two cities.
